title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, resources for transportation research and development have remained insufficient, particularly for long-term goals. Inadequate resources for long-term transportation research funding pose challenges to addressing diverse research needs effectively. The wide-ranging subject matter of transportation research makes priority setting difficult to ensure safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals are met in the United States. To meet safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals, the United States should increase federal investment in long-range transportation planning, support competitive research, coordinate research programs, share data, and establish nationwide research priorities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center, with duties outlined in the Act. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is tasked with developing a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation. It will support projects with public benefits and provide grants to research institutions for strategic transportation objectives. The National Center for Transportation Solutions awards grants to academic, public, and private research institutions to support long-term transportation objectives. It facilitates data interchange among interested parties, evaluates research programs, and coordinates with public and private research groups. The National Center for Transportation Solutions evaluates transportation research and development programs conducted by the US Government. The Director submits an annual report to Congress with recommendations on multimodal transportation research, including minority views from the Board members. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with congressional leaders. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by various officials, representing different professions and regions of the United States. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members must possess skills relevant to the Center's functions. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve staggered terms of 6, 4, or 2 years, with a limit of two consecutive terms. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members serve staggered terms of 6, 4, or 2 years, with a limit of two consecutive terms. The term of a member shall not expire during an election year. Vacancies on the Board are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board of the National Center for Transportation Solutions must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board shall meet as called by the Chair, with a majority of members constituting a quorum. The Chairman and Vice Chairman are selected from among the members and serve 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms for the Chairman. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director's term is six years, with a salary capped at the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Center is organized with the Director of National Transportation Research as the chief executive officer, appointed by the President with Senate consent for a six-year term. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee composed of at least five members to advise the Board and Director. Each division committee consists of at least five members, who may or may not be Board members. Committee members serve two-year terms and elect a Chairman annually. Committees establish their own procedures within Board restrictions. The Center has powers outlined in Section 8. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and enter into contracts to carry out the purposes of the Act. The Board and division committees have the authority to enter into cooperative agreements, including sole source agreements with the National Academy of Sciences, to assist in developing policies and strategies. They can also use the United States mails, accept gifts, and publish research results. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center may appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff responsibilities include submitting plans, developing budgets, administering programs, and providing support to the Board. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff without following civil service laws. Staff duties include submitting plans, developing budgets, administering programs, providing support to the Board, overseeing the grant program, reporting progress to the Board, and coordinating with other organizations. The Director can set compensation for personnel without restrictions on pay rates. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff without following civil service laws. Staff duties include submitting plans, developing budgets, administering programs, providing support to the Board, overseeing the grant program, reporting progress to the Board, and coordinating with other organizations. The Director can set compensation for personnel without restrictions on pay rates, including classification of positions, General Schedule pay rates, details of government employees, procurement of temporary and intermittent services, and acceptance of volunteer services. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff without following civil service laws. Staff duties include submitting plans, developing budgets, administering programs, providing support to the Board, overseeing the grant program, reporting progress to the Board, and coordinating with other organizations. The Director may accept volunteer services without regard to certain regulations. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director shall award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States. These centers will conduct research projects on regional multimodal transportation issues with long-term significance and clear public benefits. The northeast regional center will be located in a state meeting specific criteria. The northeast regional center established under this section will be located in a State with high levels of traffic congestion based on specific criteria. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
